awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support attendance by early career researchers at the annual Rust Belt RNA Meetings to be held in Columbus, OH (October 26-27, 2018); in Cleveland, OH (2019); and in Pittsburgh, PA (2020). The topics covered by the meetings include all aspects of RNA biology. The format is a combination of talks and posters, which aims to promote scientific exchange in both formal and informal settings. Additional activities, including workshops and panel discussions, will provide professional development and mentoring opportunities for early-career scientists. There will be ample opportunity for sharing latest research results and for networking. 

Recent years have witnessed breakthroughs in diverse areas of RNA science, including the epi-transcriptome, RNA-mediated regulation, functional characterization of non-coding RNAs and RNA-binding proteins, and genome-wide, multi-disciplinary approaches to decipher the networks that underlie cellular and organismal differentiation and development.  The upcoming meetings will encompass the full scope of these topics and draw regional participation to provide students and senior researchers with opportunities to learn and share RNA-related research.  Attendees will be exposed to new conceptual developments, as well as new tools, including computational, biochemical and biophysical approaches.  The meeting has and will continue to foster collaborations among diverse scientists from institutions of various types and sizes.  A hallmark of the meeting will continue to be strong participation by students at undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral levels. Scholarships and dedicated recruiting efforts will be aimed at encouraging attendance by scientists from underrepresented groups.  This meeting serves to expose students (often for the first time) to the breadth and quality of research seen at national meetings, while preserving a welcoming, informal atmosphere.  These qualities, in combination with the meeting's accessibility and affordability, make it an invaluable asset to the Midwest region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the project period, RRM has continued to facilitate scientific exchange within the community of RNA researchers around the US, primarily within the Great Lakes ?Rustbelt? region for which the meeting is named. The meeting provides a unique and extremely affordable annual venue to researchers pursuing diverse aspects of RNA science to share new results and novel approaches that impacts their ongoing and future scientific endeavors. Annual post-meeting feedback from the attendees indicates that RRM helps to establish new collaborations, interaction with experts they would not normally have had the opportunity to meet, and receive substantive feedback on their work. For two years during the pandemic, the meeting was held in virtual format. However, the 2022 RRM returned to normal by having the first post-pandemic in-person meeting.

Intellectual Impact: The intellectual impact of the RRM lies in the opportunity it provides for sharing of new (mostly unpublished) research in the broad field of RNA Biology. Recent years have witnessed numerous breakthroughs in the ability to observe, sequence, and identify noncoding and coding RNAs, their functions, and their regulatory proteins. The field of RNA biology continues to grow. The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has added to the interest in RNA biology, as the virus is encoded by a single-stranded RNA molecule and two of the highly efficacious vaccines are mRNA-based. The RRM is a fertile ground for forging interdisciplinary collaborations between researchers at diverse institutions ranging from small liberal arts colleges to large research universities. By featuring very high-quality talks and posters comparable to (and in many cases arguably better than) national and international meetings, RRM remains very conveniently located for scientists and trainees of the many academic institutions of the Great Lakes Region, who must otherwise often travel to the East or West Coasts where scientific meetings are concentrated.

Broader Impacts The broad impact of the RRM lies in its affordable yet high quality conference experience from which undergraduate, graduate, postdoctoral trainees, and faculty can participate and benefit. NSF funding has allowed us to waive the registration fees for trainees who self-identified as URMs. For all trainee attendees, RRM was also able to include lodging in the registration fee. This is crucial as it allows trainees from labs with smaller research budgets and those from PUIs to attend a high-quality conference that is also highly affordable. The meeting has maintained the rich tradition of conferring to the trainees the responsibility of presenting their research groups? findings through platform and poster presentations. 

At all the meetings held during the project period, all the oral presentations in the main sessions were by students or post-doctoral scholars except for two talks at the end which were by the new faculty. Similarly, the poster sessions featured 150+ entries each year. Trainee talks and poster presentations were judged by faculty members and senor postdoctoral scholars. Trainees were recognized for their research accomplishments via poster presentation awards and oral presentation awards.

In addition to the traditional meeting programming (research presentations), another feature of the pre-pandemic meetings (2018-2019) was a career-oriented event for trainees, which typically took shape of mentor-mentee lunch. During the project period, RRM activities were expanded to also include workshops on new emerging scientific technologies (e.g., RNA structure prediction, analysis of ?Omics? data) and on diverse non-scientific topics (e.g., mental health issues, work-life balance, creating/maintaining diverse and inclusive workplace, graduate school application process).

An additional impact of RRM is to expose the attending undergraduates to fine graduate programs located in the Great Lakes region. RRM helps to recruit talent to pursue RNA biology at these ?hidden gem? programs. At the same time, RRM continues to showcase that the inclusion of and emphasis on undergraduate training inspires students to pursue RNA biology. Last but not the least, through the persistent efforts of the RRM organizers and the steering committee, the attendance of trainees from underrepresented minorities has consistently increased over the project period. 

In summary, during the life time of the current award, RRM has upheld and even advanced the standards for a high-quality regional research conference that is widely accessible and impactful.

Modified by: Guramrit Singh
